content.rendered:
What is a Procurement Clerk?

Procurement Clerks are people who collect all purchasing orders from different departments at their company and make those purchases from suppliers/vendors.

Where does a Procurement Clerk work?

  • Government
  • Wholesale merchants
  • Offices

How much does a Procurement Clerk make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for a Procurement Clerk is $40,000.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Procurement Clerks?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing this career path.

  • Economics majors
  • Business majors
Search roles on Handshake

Procurement Clerk skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Procurement Clerks succeed in their work:

  • Good negotiation skills
  • Strong analytical skills
  • Ability to organize and juggle multiple projects

What are some common questions about Procurement Clerks?

Q: What is a procurement position?

A: People working in procurement positions are mainly responsible for organizing and analyzing a company’s purchasing demands. They make sure that all asks of their company are efficient and taken care of.

excerpt.rendered: Learn about the average salary, relevant studies, related questions, and common path after college to becoming a Procurement Clerk.
